courses.name: Exposition and Argumentation
courses.description: Stresses writing as a process, with due attention given to critical reading and thinking skills applicable to all college classes, as well as to invention, drafting, revising, and rewriting. English 1000 is a prerequisite for any Writing Intensive course.

courses.name: Honors Exposition English
courses.description: Stresses writing as a process, with due attention given to critical reading and thinking skills applicable to all college classes, as well as to invention, drafting, revising, and rewriting. English 1000 is a prerequisite for any Writing Intensive course.

courses.name: Human Language
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 1060, C_S_D 1060 and LINGST 1060). General introduction of various aspects of linguistic study. Elementary analysis of language data, with some attention to application of linguistic study to other disciplines.

courses.name: Reading Literature
courses.description: Introduces the student to the values, rigors, and pleasures of reading literature. Intended for first-year, non-English majors.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Reading Literature Series.

courses.name: Reading Literature, Beginnings to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1100 course for description.

courses.name: Reading Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1100 course for description.

courses.name: Reading Literature, 1789-1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1100 course for description.

courses.name: Reading Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1100 course for description.

courses.name: Themes in Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The Idea of Progress, Images of Women) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Themes in Literature series.

courses.name: Themes in Literature, Beginnings to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1160 for course description.

courses.name: Themes in Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1160 for course description.

courses.name: Themes in Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1160 for course description.

courses.name: Themes in Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1160 for course description.

courses.name: Readings in British Literature
courses.description: Focuses on reading and interpreting selected texts in British literature.  No more than six hours may be taken in Readings in British Literature Series.

courses.name: Readings in British Literature, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1200 for course description.

courses.name: Readings in British Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1200 for course description.

courses.name: Readings in British Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1200 for course description.

courses.name: Readings in British Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1200 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to British Literature
courses.description: A basic introduction to the concepts, terms, and practices commonly encountered in literary study, presented by way of texts from the history of British literature that appropriately demonstrate such concepts, terms, and practices. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to British Literature
courses.description: A basic introduction to the concepts, terms, and practices commonly encountered in literary study, presented by way of texts from the history of British literature that appropriately demonstrate such concepts, terms, and practices. This course is recommended for prospective majors.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Readings in American Literature
courses.description: Focuses on reading and interpreting selected texts in American literature. No more than six hours may be taken in the Readings in American Literature series.

courses.name: Readings in American Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1300 for course description.

courses.name: Readings in American Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1300 for course description.

courses.name: Readings in American Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: See ENGLSH 1300 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to American Literature
courses.description: A basic introduction to the concepts, terms, and practices commonly encountered in literary study, presented by way of texts from the history of American literature that appropriately demonstrate such concepts, terms, and practices. Graded on A/F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to American Literature - Honors
courses.description: A basic introduction to the concepts, terms, and practices commonly encountered in literary study, presented by way of texts from the history of American literature that appropriately demonstrates such concepts, terms, and practices.  Graded A-F basis only.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Introduction to Fiction
courses.description: Introduces basic narrative techniques, including writing original stories.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Introduction to Nonfiction Prose
courses.description: Introduces the range and basic techniques of creative nonfiction, including composing original work in the genre.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Introduction to Poetry
courses.description: Introduces basic poetic techniques, including writing original poems.

courses.name: Introduction to Folklore Genres
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 1150).  Course focus is on genres of folklore in both historic and contemporary contexts, as well as in people's daily lives.  Genres include narrative, proverbs, oral poetry and rhyme, riddles, jokes, legends, epics, material culture and intangible expressive culture.  Graded on A/F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Folklore Genres - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 1150).  Course focus is on genres of folklore in both historic and contemporary contexts, as well as in people's daily lives.  Genres include narrative, proverbs, oral poetry and rhyme, riddles, jokes, legends, epics, material culture and intangible expressive culture.  Graded on A/F basis only.

courses.name: Introduction to Film Studies
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 1800, DST 1800).  Introduction to terms and concepts for film analysis, including mise-en-scene, cinematography, editing, sound narrative, genre, and other elements. No credit for students who have completed FILM_S 2810.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: freshman and sophomores only or instructor's consent

courses.name: Introduction to Digital Media Production
courses.description: (same as DST 1880; FILM_S 1880).  Introduction to concepts and skills for Digital Storytelling, including media literacy and forms of narrative manifested historically and currently across a range of media. This course focuses on theories and concepts that support the critical analysis and creation of contemporary narrative in digital form with particular attention to audio, visual and written communication. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Studies in English
courses.description: Underclass topics. Subjects vary from semester to semester. No more than six hours may be taken in the Topics in English Studies series.

courses.name: Studies in English - Honors
courses.description: Underclass topics. Subjects vary from semester to semester. No more than six hours may be taken in the Topics in English Studies series.

courses.name: Studies in English - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Underclass topics. Subjects vary from semester to semester. No more than six hours may be taken in the Topics in English Studies series.

courses.name: Topics in English - Humanities
courses.description: Underclass topics. Subjects vary from semester to semester. May be repeated to 6 hours maximum.

courses.name: Studies in English, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2000 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in English, Beginning to 1603 - Writing Intensive
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2000 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in English, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2000 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in English, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2000 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in English, 1890 to Present
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2000 for course description.

courses.name: Intermediate Composition
courses.description: Provides intensive guided practice in expository and persuasive writing.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Tutoring Writing Seminar - Honors
courses.description: (same as GN_HON 2015H).  Addresses both the theory and practice of tutoring and the foundations of good writing.  This course also qualifies students for a part-time job working as Writing Lab/Online Writery tutors in future semester.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 1000; instructor's consent. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Tutoring Writing Seminar - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as GN_HON 2015H).  Addresses both the theory and practice of tutoring and the foundations of good writing.  This course also qualifies students for a part-time job working as Writing Lab/Online Writery tutors in future semester.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 1000; instructor's consent. Honors eligibility required

courses.name: Professional Writing
courses.description: Introduction to the communication required in any professional field, including basic letters and resumes, reviews, reports, and electronic networking, culminating in an extensive report and a related oral presentation.

courses.name: Writing About Literature
courses.description: Introduces the student to reading in three or four genres (fiction, poetry, drama, and non-fiction) and to literary concepts and terms and their application in literary analysis.

courses.name: Writing About Literature - Honors
courses.description: Introduces the student to reading in three or four genres (fiction, poetry, drama, and non-fiction) and to literary concepts and terms and their application in literary analysis.

courses.name: Twentieth-Century Literature
courses.description: A multi-genre survey emphasizing American and British works within the intellectual and cultural context of our time.

courses.name: Twentieth-Century Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: A multi-genre survey emphasizing American and British works within the intellectual and cultural context of our time.

courses.name: Popular Literature
courses.description: Study of literary genres, such as science fiction and the detective novel, that may be overlooked in traditional literature classes.

courses.name: Popular Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Study of literary genres, such as science fiction and the detective novel, that may be overlooked in traditional literature classes.

courses.name: Introduction to World Literatures
courses.description: Presents and puts into context works by writers from different nations or ethnic backgrounds; includes works in two or more literary genres.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Introduction to World Literature series.

courses.name: Introduction to World Literatures, Beginnings to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2155 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to World Literatures, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2155 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to World Literatures, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2155 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to World Literatures, 1890 to Present
courses.description: Presents and puts into context works by writers from different nations or ethnic backgrounds, includes works in two or more literary genres. No more than six hours may be taken in the Introduction to World Literature series.

courses.name: Major Authors
courses.description: Focuses on the works of a single writer (e.g., Shakespeare) or set of writers (e.g., William Faulkner and Flannery O'Connor). Topic announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Major Authors series.

courses.name: Major Authors, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2160 for course description.

courses.name: Major Authors, 1603 TO 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2160 for course description.

courses.name: Major Authors, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2160 for course description.

courses.name: Major Authors, 1890 to Present
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2160 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to Women's Literature
courses.description: (same as WGST 2180). A study of traditional and nontraditional literature written by women from the perspective of feminist themes-love, power, work, family and other relations. No more than six hours may be taken in the Introduction to Women's Literature series.

courses.name: Introduction to Women's Literature, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: (same as WGST 2186). See ENGLSH 2180 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to Women's Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as WGST 2187). See ENGLSH 2180 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to Women's Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: (same as WGST 2188). See ENGLSH 2180 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to Women's Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: (same as WGST 2189). See ENGLSH 2180 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to Women's Literature, 1890 to Present - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as WGST 2189). See ENGLSH 2180 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in British Literature
courses.description: Topic (e.g., Gothic Literature, The Domestic Novel) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Topics in British Literature series.

courses.name: Studies in British Literature - Honors
courses.description: Topic (e.g., Gothic Literature, The Domestic Novel) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Topics in British Literature series.

courses.name: Studies in British Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Topic (e.g., Gothic Literature, The Domestic Novel) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Topics in British Literature series.

courses.name: Studies in British Literature, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2200 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in British Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2200 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in British Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2200 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in British Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2200 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in British Literature, 1890 to Present - Writing Intensive
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2200 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in American Literature
courses.description: Topic (e.g., American Culture, The Frontier) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Topics in American Literature series.

courses.name: Studies in American Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Topic (e.g., American Culture, The Frontier) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Topics in American Literature series.

courses.name: Studies in American Literature, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2300 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in American Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2300 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in American Literature, 1789-1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2300 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in American Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2300 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in American Literature, 1890 to Present - Writing Intensive
courses.description: See ENGLSH 2300 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to African Diaspora Literature
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 2400). Introduces students to African Diaspora literature with an emphasis on literature written originally in English. No more than six hours may be taken in the Introduction to African Diaspora Literature series.

courses.name: Introduction to African Diaspora Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 2407).  See ENGLSH 2400 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to African Diaspora Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 2408).  See ENGLSH 2400 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to African Diaspora Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 2409).  See ENGLSH 2400 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to Native Studies
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 2490). Introduction to the field of Native Studies. Topics include indigenous knowledge, culture change and continuity, history and misrepresentation, politics and political history, and global indigenous relationships. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Intermediate Fiction
courses.description: Provides intensive guided practice in the writing of short fiction.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Intermediate Nonfiction Prose
courses.description: Provides guided practice in the writing of creative nonfiction.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Intermediate Poetry
courses.description: Provides intensive guided practice in the writing of poetry.

courses.name: Beginning Playwriting
courses.description: (same as THEATR 2920). Study and practice of playwriting fundamentals; emphasizes the one-act play.

courses.name: Languages of Africa
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 2601, LINGST 2601). Introduction to the diversity of the 2000+ African languages, including first-hand experience exploring a few in detail with native speakers.  Features of African languages are compared with others of the world.  Political and social aspects of language in Africa are discussed.

courses.name: Introduction to Folklore Field Research
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 2150). Course will focus on the specifics of how to identify, collect, preserve and document folklore within communities.

courses.name: Introduction to Oral Literature
courses.description: An introduction to works of verbal art from living oral tradition (e.g. Native American and African-American) and to some of our most important literary works with roots in oral tradition (e.g., the Bible, the Iliad, and the Odyssey, and Beowulf).

courses.name: American Film History I, 1895-1950
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 2830). Examines the development of American cinema in relation to other national cinemas, from 1895-1950. No credit for students who have completed ENGLSH  1810 or FILM_S 1810.

courses.name: American Film History II, 1950-Present
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 2840). Examines American film history in an international context, from 1950-present.  No credit for students who have completed ENGLSH 1820 or FILM_S 1820.

courses.name: Film Themes and Genres
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 2860, DST 2860).  Topics (e.g. Film noir, African-American filmmakers, Food and Film, The Western) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in ENGLSH 2680.

courses.name: Film and Literature
courses.description: (same as  FILM_S 2870).  Explores the complex interplay between film and literature in order to gain an understanding of the possibilities - and problems - involved in the transposition from literature to film.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Digital Storytelling Production I
courses.description: (same as DST 2880). Digital Storytelling Production I teaches agility with digital video technology through applied experiences. Assignments in digital video production emphasize how video narratives are created and how images and audio enhance the structure, mood, and theme of the narrative. Instruction will focus on planning a video production and developing the tools and practices in lighting, sound recording, image capturing, and editing. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Digital Storytelling Animation Production I
courses.description: (same as DST 2885). Introduction to all aspects of digital animation and elements of the 3D computer animation production pipeline, including story drafting and production planning, polygonal modeling and texturing, rigging, key framing, lighting, compositing rendered images, and editing into a short finished film. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Service Learning in English
courses.description: Students perform volunteer service and complete course requirements, which may include class meetings and written and oral assignments. May be repeated with departmental consent. Graded on a S/U basis only. Does not meet A&S general education requirements.

courses.name: Advanced Composition
courses.description: An intensive writing workshop in which student essays and related texts receive close reading and analysis. Focus (e.g. The Essay, The Research Paper) announced at time of registration.

courses.name: Sexuality and Gender Theory
courses.description: (same as [WGST] 3080). Examination of major theoretical approaches and debates in the study of gender and sexuality, with particular attention to the intersection of culture, representation, and identity. May be repeated to 6 hours with department consent.

courses.name: Introduction to Literary Theory
courses.description: Introduction to the range of theoretical approaches to the study of literature; intended as a broad survey of literary theory, whether from the Classical era onward or 20th century literary theory and beyond.

courses.name: Special Themes in Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Postmodernism, Representations of Nature) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Special Themes in Literature series.

courses.name: Special Themes in Literature - Honors
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Postmodernism, Representations of Nature) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Special Themes in Literature series.

courses.name: Special Themes in Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Postmodernism, Representations of Nature) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Special Themes in Literature series.

courses.name: Special Themes in Literature, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 3110 for course descriptions.

courses.name: Special Themes in Literature, Beginning to 1603 - Writing Intensive
courses.description: See ENGLSH 3110 for course descriptions.

courses.name: Special Themes in Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 3110 for course descriptions.

courses.name: Special Themes in Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: See ENGLSH 3110 for course descriptions.

courses.name: Special Themes in Literature, 1789 to 1890 - Honors
courses.description: See ENGLSH 3110H for course descriptions.

courses.name: Special Themes in Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: See ENGLSH 3110 for course descriptions.

courses.name: World Dramatic Literature
courses.description: (same as THEATR 3700). Survey of world drama from Greeks to present, focusing on structure, theory, and performance. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: World Dramatic Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as THEATR 3700). Survey of world drama from Greeks to present, focusing on structure, theory, and performance. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Survey of Women Writers
courses.description: (same as WGST 3180). A study of writing by women from the Middle Ages to the present.

courses.name: Survey of Women Writers - Honors
courses.description: A study of writing by women from the Middle Ages to the present.

courses.name: Survey of Women Writers - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as WGST 3180). A study of writing by women from the Middle Ages to the present.

courses.name: Survey of British Literature: Beginnings to 1784
courses.description: Historical survey from beginnings of British literature through the age of Johnson, with readings representing significant writers, works and currents of thought.

courses.name: Survey of British Literature: Romanticism to the Present
courses.description: Historical survey of British literature from the Romantic period to the present, emphasizing important writers and significant intellectual and cultural movements.

courses.name: Survey of British Literature: Romanticism to the Present - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Historical survey of British literature from the Romantic period to the present, emphasizing important writers and significant intellectual and cultural movements.

courses.name: Survey of American Literature: Beginnings to 1865
courses.description: A survey of major writers and movements in American literature from Colonialism to Romanticism.

courses.name: Survey of American Literature: Beginnings to 1865 - Writing Intensive
courses.description: A survey of major writers and movements in American literature from Colonialism to Romanticism.

courses.name: Survey of American Literature: 1865-Present
courses.description: A survey of major writers and movements in American literature from realism to postmodernism.

courses.name: Survey of American Literature: 1865-Present - Writing Intensive
courses.description: A survey of major writers and movements in American literature from realism to postmodernism.

courses.name: Survey of African American Literature, Beginnings to 1900
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 3400). A survey of major authors and movements in African American literature from its beginnings to 1900.

courses.name: Survey of African American Literature, Beginnings to 1900 - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 3400). A survey of major authors and movements in African American literature from its beginnings to 1900.

courses.name: Survey of African American Literature, 1900-Present
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 3410). A survey of major authors and movements in African American literature from 1900 to the present.

courses.name: Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 3420). Topic (e.g. Harlem Renaissance African Diaspora  Poetry) Announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature series.

courses.name: Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 3427).  See ENGLSH 3420 for course description.

courses.name: Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 3428).  See ENGLSH 3420 for course description.

courses.name: Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 3429).  See ENGLSH 3420 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to African Diaspora Literary Theory
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 3705).  Introduction to the range of theoretical approaches to the study of African Diaspora literature, with particular attention to the diverse socio-political contexts that undergird range of literary, historical, and cultural theories; intended as a broad survey of African Diaspora literary theory, whether from the Slavery era onward or 20th century literary theory and beyond. May be repeated for credit with consent.

courses.name: Native Writing and Representation
courses.description: (same as PEA_ST 3490).  Survey of native writing and representation from the late eighteenth century to the present, encompassing a diverse range of tribes and forms. Material will be drawn from tribes inhabiting the North American continent, but global indigenous relationships will also be addressed. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Intermediate Playwriting
courses.description: (same as THEATR 3920). Intermediate study of the writing process as applied to theatre, leading to the creation of a full-length play to be considered for production.

courses.name: Performance of Literature
courses.description: (same as COMMUN 3570 and THEATR 3200). Analysis and oral interpretation of literary works. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: American Folklore
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 3150). Focus on regional and ethnic folklore; emphasis on analysis of folklore in context. Requirements include book reports and two analytical papers based on student field research.

courses.name: Major Directors
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 3820, RM_LAN 3820). Topics (e.g. Hitchcock, Kubrick, Fellini, Allen, Kurosawa, Wilder) announced at time of registration.  Only 6 hours may be taken for credit toward major.  Graded on A/F basis only.

courses.name: Studies in Film History
courses.description: (same as  FILM_S 3850).  Topics (e.g. Classical Period of Hollywood cinema, silent era, Post-WWII American film, German Weimar cinema, French New Wave) announced at time of registration.  Only 6 hours count as credit toward major.

courses.name: Documentary Film
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 3855, DST 3855).  Surveys the history of documentary film including the development of subgenres, sound and voice over in documentary, re-enactment, ethical issues in documentary film production, and more.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Writing and Theory for Digital Media
courses.description: (same as DST 3880). Writing and Theory for Digital Media teaches the skills, methods and theoretical frameworks needed to write for new media. Students will study and practice writing for web-based and digital media platforms, including short-form modes such as Twitter and various social media sites; longer-form modes such as blogs, vlogs and podcasts; and the emerging possibilities of locative and interactive media. Assignments emphasize the professional and creative possibilities of new media production. In addition to the hands-on creation for audio, screen-based, networked, and hybrid forms of digital media, students will also read, discuss, and write about work by new media theorists. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Writing and Theory for Digital Media  - Writing Intensive
courses.description: methods and theoretical frameworks needed to write for new media. Students will study and practice writing for web-based and digital media platforms, including short-form modes such as Twitter and various social media sites; longer-form modes such as blogs, vlogs and podcasts; and the emerging possibilities of locative and interactive media. Assignments emphasize the professional and creative possibilities of new media production. In addition to the hands-on creation for audio, screen-based, networked, and hybrid forms of digital media, students will also read, discuss, and write about work by new media theorists. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Advanced Studies in English
courses.description: Advanced examination of subjects within English studies. Subjects vary from semester to semester. May repeat to six hours.

courses.name: Advanced Studies in English - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Advanced examination of subjects within English studies. Subjects vary from semester to semester. May repeat to six hours.

courses.name: Topics in English-Social Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May repeat to six hours.

courses.name: Studies in Writing
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7040). A hybrid reading/writing course that focuses on a form of nonfiction prose, such as the experimental essay, art criticism, book reviews, spiritual writing, nature writing, etc. This course is not a workshop, although it may incorporate workshop elements. Designed for English majors who may or may not have taken creative writing courses. May repeat to six hours with departmental consent.

courses.name: Studies in Writing - Writing Intensive
courses.description: A hybrid reading/writing course that focuses on a form of nonfiction prose, such as the experimental essay, art criticism, book reviews, spiritual writing, nature writing, etc. This course is not a workshop, although it may incorporate workshop elements. Designed for English majors who may or may not have taken creative writing courses. May repeat to six hours with departmental consent.

courses.name: Rhetorical Studies
courses.description: Examines questions  related to rhetoric, the study of symbols used for persuasion, justification, or communication.  Specific topics are announced at time of registration and may involve the rhetorical study of fiction or nonfiction, oral or written texts, verbal or visual modes.

courses.name: Historical Survey of Rhetoric
courses.description: A survey of major works of rhetoric from Plato to the present day, with special attention to those works influencing English language rhetorics and theories of rhetoric.

courses.name: Studies in Critical Theory
courses.description: Focuses on questions raised by various critical theories, includes practice writing criticism that applies the theories to particular works. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: History of Criticism
courses.description: Surveys modern and contemporary theories of literary criticism: historical, archetypal, generic, formalist, phenomenological and interdisciplinary. Emphasizes key writers in each field.

courses.name: Genres
courses.description: Advanced survey of major movements and writers. Topics (e.g., American Poetry, The Development of the British Novel) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Genres series.

courses.name: Genres - Honors
courses.description: Advanced survey of major movements and writers. Topics (e.g., American Poetry, The Development of the British Novel) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Genres series.

courses.name: Genres - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: Advanced survey of major movements and writers. Topics (e.g., American Poetry, The Development of the British Novel) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Genres series.

courses.name: Genres - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Advanced survey of major movements and writers. Topics (e.g., American Poetry, The Development of the British Novel) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Genres series.

courses.name: Genres, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 4100 for course description.

courses.name: World Literatures
courses.description: Study of important works and writers from Asia, Africa, Europe, Latin America or the mid-East. Topics (e.g., Survey of World Literature, The Bible) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the World Literature series.

courses.description: Intensive study of the work of a single writer (e.g., Milton) or set of writers (e.g., Whitman and Dickinson). Topic announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Major Author series.

courses.name: Major Authors, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 4160 for course description.

courses.name: Comparative Approaches to Literature
courses.description: Study of works separated by the places or eras of their composition, but united by themes or traditions. Topics (e.g., Poets of African Diaspora, Literatures of Exile) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Comparative Approaches to Literature.

courses.name: Comparative Approaches to Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Study of works separated by the places or eras of their composition, but united by themes or traditions. Topics (e.g., Poets of African Diaspora, Literatures of Exile) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Comparative Approaches to Literature.

courses.name: Major Women Writers
courses.description: (same as WGST 4180). Study of a limited number (1-3) of significant writers to be read intensively using contemporary feminist critical theory. No more than six hours may be taken in the Major Women Writers series.

courses.name: Themes in Literature by Women
courses.description: (same as WGST 4181 and BL_STU 4181). Examines works by a number of women writers with particular attention to their socio-political context. May repeated to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Major Women Writers, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: (same as WGST 4186). See ENGLSH 4180 for course description.

courses.name: Major Women Writers, 1603-1789
courses.description: (same as WGST 4187). See ENGLSH 4180 for course description.

courses.name: Major Women Writers, 1789-1890

courses.description: (same as WGST 4188). See ENGLSH 4180 for course description.

courses.name: Major Women Writers, 1890-Present
courses.description: (same as WGST 4189). See ENGLSH 4180 for course description.

courses.name: Introduction to Old English
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4200). A beginning study of the Old English or Anglo-Saxon language in its cultural context, with emphasis on gaining a reading knowledge.

courses.name: Anglo-Saxon Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7206). Readings in the literature of Anglo-Saxon England (ca.500-ca.1100 C.E.). Specific topics (e.g., Women in the Early Middle Ages, Beowulf, Old English Heroic Poetry) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Medieval Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7210). Topics (e.g., Age of Chaucer, Chivalry and Courtly Love, Allegory and Satire) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Renaissance and Seventeenth Century Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The Metaphysical Poets, Themes in Shakespeare) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Renaissance and Seventeenth Century Literature.

courses.name: Renaissance and Seventeenth Century Literature, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 4220 for course description.

courses.name: Renaissance and Seventeenth Century Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 4220 for course description.

courses.name: Restoration and 18th-Century English Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Restoration Drama, Johnson and his Circle) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 19th-Century English Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7250). Topics (e.g., Victorian Poetry, Non-Fiction Prose) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 19th-Century English Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7250). Topics (e.g., Victorian Poetry, Non-Fiction Prose) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 20th-Century British Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7260). Topics (e.g. Contemporary British Poets, The Post-War Novel) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 20th-Century British Literature - Honors
courses.description: Topics (e.g. Contemporary British Poets, The Post-War Novel) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 20th-Century British Literature - Honors/Writing Intensive
courses.description: Topics (e.g. Contemporary British Poets, The Post-War Novel) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 20th-Century British Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7260). Topics (e.g. Contemporary British Poets, The Post-War Novel) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Early American Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Narratives of Discovery and Exploration, The Puritan Heritage) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 19th-Century American Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7310). Topics (e.g., American Romanticism, Regionalism) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 19th-Century American Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7310). Topics (e.g., American Romanticism, Regionalism) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 20th-Century American Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7320). Topics (e.g., American Poetry since T. S. Eliot, The Short Story) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 20th-Century American Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7320). Topics (e.g., American Poetry since T. S. Eliot, The Short Story) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Studies in African Diaspora Literature
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4400). Topics (e.g., African American Poetry, Africana Diaspora Drama) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Studies in Africana Literature series.

courses.name: Studies in African Diaspora Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4407). See ENGLSH 4400 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in African Diaspora Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4408). See ENGLSH 4400 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in African Diaspora Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4407). See ENGLSH 4400 for course description.

courses.name: Major Africana Diaspora Writers
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4410). An intensive study of selected writers of African Diaspora literature focusing on texts originally in English. No more than six hours may be taken in the Major African Diaspora Writers series.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Writers, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4417). See ENGLSH 4410 for course description.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Writers, 1789-1890
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4418). See ENGLSH 4410 for course description.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Writers, 1890 to Present
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4419). See ENGLSH 4410 for course description.

courses.name: Africana Womanism
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 4420). An intensive study of Africana Womanism, focusing on selected Africana women writers. May be repeated to six hours with departmental consent.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Women Writers
courses.description: (same as WGST 4480 and BL_STU 4480). Study of selected Africana Diaspora women writers, focusing on texts originally in English. Maybe repeated for credit with departmental consent.  Maximum of 6 hours for ENGLSH 4180 and ENGLSH 4480.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Women Writers - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as WGST 4480 and BL_STU 4480). Study of selected Africana Diaspora women writers, focusing on texts originally in English. Maybe repeated for credit with departmental consent.  Maximum of 6 hours for ENGLSH 4180 and ENGLSH 4480.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Women Writers, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as WGST 4487 and BL_STU 4487). See ENGLSH 4480 for course description.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Women Writers, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: (same as WGST 4488 and BL_STU 4488). See ENGLSH 4480 for course description.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Women Writers, 1890 to Present
courses.description: (same as WGST 4489 and BL_STU 4489). See ENGLSH 4480 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in Native American and Indigenous Studies
courses.description: In-depth study of topics in Native American and Indigenous Studies, such as tribal intellectual histories, defined historical periods, or specific genres or media.  Examples of course titles include Ojibwe Writing, Native Film and Video, and Contemporary Native Literature.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Advanced Fiction
courses.description: An intensive writing workshop in which student stories and related literary texts receive close reading and analysis.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Advanced Fiction - Writing Intensive
courses.description: An intensive writing workshop in which student stories and related literary texts receive close reading and analysis.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Advanced Nonfiction Prose
courses.description: An intensive writing workshop in which a student's creative nonfiction receives close reading and analysis.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Advanced Nonfiction Prose - Writing Intensive
courses.description: An intensive writing workshop in which a student's creative nonfiction receives close reading and analysis.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Advanced Poetry
courses.description: Poetry regarded as a mode of understanding. Poetic values related to other values. Practical consideration of verse techniques.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Advanced Poetry - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Poetry regarded as a mode of understanding. Poetic values related to other values. Practical consideration of verse techniques.

courses.name: Advanced Playwriting: Problems
courses.description: (same as THEATR 4920; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7560 and THEATR 7920). Advanced study of the writing process as applied to theatre, including theory and practice. Special playwriting problems and techniques.

courses.name: Advanced Playwriting: Problems - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as THEATR 4920; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7560 and THEATR 7920). Advanced study of the writing process as applied to theatre, including theory and practice. Special playwriting problems and techniques.

courses.name: Adaptation of Literature for the Stage
courses.description: (same as THEATR 4930; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7570 and THEATR 7930). Explores adaptation principles and practices with literature not originally written for the stage.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Structure of American English
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4600). Introduction to English linguistics. Study of the grammar and pronunciation of contemporary English, with the major focus on syntax.

courses.name: History of the English Language
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4610). Historical changes in the grammar and pronunciation of the English language from Old English to the present. Introduction to Indo-European origins of English.

courses.name: Regional and Social Dialects of American English
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4620). The study of regional and social variation in pronunciation, vocabulary, and grammar of American English.

courses.name: Phonology
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4630). Survey of the sound patterns of English, with some comparison to other languages.

courses.name: Syntax
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4640). Study of the properties of phrase-and sentence-level grammar, emphasizing English, with some comparison to other languages.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 4600 or another comparable linguistics course

courses.name: Field Methods in Linguistics
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4870 and ANTHRO 4870). Provides training in the methods of constructing a detailed linguistic description and analysis of wholly unfamiliar language, based on interviews with a native speaker.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Field Methods in Linguistics - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as LINGST 4870 and ANTHRO 4870). Provides training in the methods of constructing a detailed linguistic description and analysis of wholly unfamiliar language, based on interviews with a native speaker.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Special Themes in Folklore
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 4150). Intensive study in a selected area of folklore: folk narrative, folk song, myth, proverb, etc., folklore of a particular group. May be repeated for a maximum of six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Themes in African Diaspora Folklore
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 4160 and BL_STU 4710). Intensive study in a selected area of African Diaspora folklore: folk narrative, folk song, myth, proverb, etc., folklore and literature; or the folklore of a particular group. ENGLSH 4700 and ENGLSH 4710 may be repeated for a maximum of six hours with instructor's consent.

courses.name: Oral Tradition
courses.description: (same as CL_HUM 4770). Study of verbal art from living oral traditions (e.g., Native American and African American) and important literary works with roots in oral tradition (e.g., the Bible, the Iliad, the Odyssey, and Beowulf).

courses.name: Women's Folklore and Feminist Theory
courses.description: (same as WGST 4780). Examines folklore and artistic expression of women in relation to feminist theory and in multicultural contexts. Includes verbal genres (narrative/ song) as well as material genres (quilting/arts).

courses.name: Film Theory
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 4810, DST 4810). This course explores contemporary trends in film theory. Topics may include: psychoanalysis, feminism, Marxism, cultural studies, queer theory, audience and star studies, postcolonialism, among others.

courses.name: Studies in Film Genre
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 4820). Topics (e.g. The Western, Film Noir) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken for credit toward the major.

courses.name: Culture and Media
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 4840, DST 4840). Topics (e.g. Cinema and Imperialism, Indigenous Media, Ethnographic Documentary) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken for credit toward the major.

courses.name: Digital Storytelling Production II
courses.description: (same as DST 4880). Digital Storytelling Production II introduces students to advanced techniques in digital storytelling production, while further developing skills in script writing, storyboarding, Adobe Premiere Pro, and video production with DSLR cameras. Assignments in digital video production emphasize how video narratives are created and how images and audio enhance the structure, mood, and theme of the narrative. Instruction will focus on planning a video production and developing the tools and practices in lighting, sound recording, image capturing, and editing. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 1000, ENGLSH 1880/DST 1880, and sophomore standing, or consent of instructor

courses.name: Adaptation of Literature for Film
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 4935 and THEATR 4935; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7580, FILM_S 7935 and THEATR 7935). This upper-division course will explore adaptation principles and practices with a variety of forms of literature that were not originally written for film.

courses.name: Advanced Screenwriting: Styles
courses.description: (same as THEATR 4938; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7938, THEATR 7938). Students develop advanced skills of screenwriting through a focus on non-realistic, non-linear dramatic writing styles in development of a full-length screenplay. Areas of study will include techniques of magic realism, symbolism, expressionism, absurdism, surrealism/dada, mythic/fantasy, musicals, political docudrama, and science fiction.

courses.name: Internship in English
courses.description: Students work in an agency or institution using their English-related skills for one to three credit hours. Graded on an S/U basis only.

courses.name: Internship in Publishing
courses.description: Offers practical experience working with a literary or scholarly publication edited or sponsored by faculty members. Graduate students in English must take the course two semesters in order to count three hours toward the completion of their program.

courses.name: Independent Research in English
courses.description: Development of a carefully considered research project under close supervision of a faculty member. Open to undergraduate students only.

courses.name: Special Readings in English
courses.description: Individual work with conferences adjusted to needs of student.

courses.name: Capstone Experience
courses.description: For students in their last semester, this course focuses on a major project and the processes of selection, research, and writing leading to its completion. Includes a professional component (resume, cover letter).

courses.name: Capstone Experience - Writing Intensive
courses.description: For students in their last semester, this course focuses on a major project and the processes of selection, research, and writing leading to its completion. Includes a professional component (resume, cover letter).

courses.name: Senior Honors Thesis
courses.description: Independent research under direction of faculty.  Second course of two part Honors Sequence.

courses.name: Honors Seminar in English
courses.description: First of two major semester Honors sequence.  Studies literary topic, critical approaches and advanced literary research methodology in preparation for Honors Senior Thesis.

courses.name: Honors Seminar in English - Writing Intensive
courses.description: First of two major semester Honors sequence.  Studies literary topic, critical approaches and advanced literary research methodology in preparation for Honors Senior Thesis.

courses.name: Topics in English-Social Science
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May repeat to six hours.

courses.name: Studies in Writing
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4040). A hybrid reading/writing course that focuses on a form of nonfiction prose, such as the experimental essay, art criticism, book reviews, spiritual writing, nature writing, etc. This course is not a workshop, although it may incorporate workshop elements. Designed for students who may or may not have taken previous creative writing courses. May repeat to six hours with departmental consent.

courses.name: Rhetorical Studies
courses.description: Examines questions related to rhetoric, the study of symbols used for persuasion, justification, or communication.  Specific topics are announced at time of registration and may involve the rhetorical study of fiction or nonfiction, oral or written texts, verbal or visual modes.

courses.name: Historical Survey of Rhetoric
courses.description: A survey of major works of rhetoric from Plato to the present day, with special attention to those works influencing English language rhetoric's and theories of rhetoric.

courses.name: Studies in Critical Theory
courses.description: Focuses on questions raised by various critical theories, includes practice writing criticism that applies the theories to particular works. May repeat to six hours with departmental consent.

courses.name: History of Criticism
courses.description: Surveys modern and contemporary theories of literary criticism: historical, archetypal, generic, formalist, phenomenological and interdisciplinary. Emphasizes key writers in each field.

courses.name: Genres
courses.description: Advanced survey of major movements and writers. Topics (e.g., American Poetry, The Development of the British Novel) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Genres series.

courses.description: See ENGLSH 7100 for course description.

courses.name: Anglo-Saxon Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4206). Readings in the literature of Anglo-Saxon England (ca.500-ca.1100 C.E.). Specific topics (e.g., Women in the Early Middle Ages, Beowulf, Old English Heroic Poetry) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Medieval Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4210). Topics (e.g., Age of Chaucer, Chivalry and Courtly Love, Allegory and Satire) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Renaissance and 17th-Century English Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The Metaphysical Poets, Themes in Shakespeare) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Renaissance and Seventeenth Century Literature series.

courses.name: Renaissance and Seventeenth Century Literature, Beginning to 1603
courses.description: See ENGLSH 7220 for course description.

courses.name: Renaissance and Seventeenth Century Literature, 1603-1789
courses.description: See ENGLSH 7220 for course description.

courses.name: Restoration and 18th-Century English Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Restoration Drama, Johnson and his Circle) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 19th-Century English Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4250). Topics (e.g., Victorian Poetry, Non-Fiction Prose) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 20th-Century British Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4260). Topics (e.g. Contemporary British Poets, The Post-War Novel) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Early American Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Narratives of Discovery and Exploration, The Puritan Heritage) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 19th-Century American Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4310). Topics (e.g., American Romanticism, Regionalism) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: 20th-Century American Literature
courses.description: (cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4320). Topics (e.g., American Poetry since T. S. Eliot, The Short Story) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Studies in African Diaspora Literature
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 7400). Topics (e.g., African American Poetry, African Diaspora Drama) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Studies in African Diaspora Literature series.

courses.name: Studies in African Diaspora Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 7407). See ENGLSH 7400 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in African Diaspora Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 7408). See ENGLSH 7400 for course description.

courses.name: Studies in African Diaspora  Literature, 1890-to Present
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 7407). See ENGLSH 7400 for course description.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Writers
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 7410). An intensive study of selected writers of African Diaspora literature, focusing on texts originally in English. No more than six hours may be taken in the Major African Diaspora Writers series.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Writers, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 7417). See ENGLSH 7410 for course description.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Writers, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 7418). See ENGLSH 7410 for course description.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Writers, 1890 to Present
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 7419). See ENGLSH 7410 for course description.

courses.name: Africana Womanism
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 7420). An intensive study of Africana Womanism, focusing on selected Africana women writers.
courses.prerequisites: graduate standing or instructor's consent. May be repeated to six hours with departmental consent

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Women Writers
courses.description: (same as WGST 7480 and BL_STU 7480). Study of selected African Diaspora women writers, focusing on texts originally in English. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.  Maximum of 6 hours for ENGLSH 7180 and ENGLSH 7480

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Women Writers, 1603 to 1789
courses.description: (same as WGST 7487 and BL_STU 7487). See ENGLSH 7480 for course description.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Women Writers, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: (same as WGST 7488 and BL_STU 7488). See ENGLSH 7480 for course description.

courses.name: Major African Diaspora Women Writers, 1789 to 1890
courses.description: (same as WGST 7489 and BL_STU 7489). See ENGLSH 7480 for course description.

courses.name: Native Studies
courses.description: In-depth study of topics in Native writing and representation, such as tribal intellectual histories, defined historical periods, or specific genres or media.  Examples of course titles include Ojibwe Writing, Native Film and Video, and Contemporary Native Literature.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Advanced Fiction
courses.description: An intensive writing workshop in which student stories and related literary texts receive close reading and analysis.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Advanced Nonfiction Prose
courses.description: An intensive writing workshop in which a student's creative nonfiction receives close reading and analysis.

courses.name: Creative Writing: Advanced Poetry
courses.description: Poetry regarded as a mode of understanding. Poetic values related to other values. Practical consideration of verse techniques.

courses.name: Advanced Playwriting: Problems
courses.description: (same as THEATR 7920; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4650 and THEATR 4920). Advanced study of the writing process as applied to theatre, including theory and practice. Special playwriting problems and techniques.

courses.name: Adaptation of Literature for the Stage
courses.description: (same as THEATR 7930; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4570). Explores adaptation principles and practices with a variety of forms of literature that were not originally written for the stage.

courses.name: Adaptation of Literature for Film
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 7935 and THEATR 7935; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4935, FILM_S 4935 and THEATR 4935).  This upper division course will explore adaptation principles and practices with a variety of forms of literature that were not originally written for film.

courses.name: Structure of American English
courses.description: (same as LINGST 7600). Introduction to English linguistics. Study of the grammar and pronunciation of contemporary English, with the major focus on syntax.

courses.name: History of the English Language
courses.description: (same as LINGST 7610). Historical changes in the grammar and pronunciation of the English language from Old English to the present. Introduction to Indo-European origins of English.

courses.name: Regional and Social Dialects of American English
courses.description: (same as LINGST 7620). The study of regional and social variation in pronunciation, vocabulary, and grammar of American English.

courses.name: Phonology
courses.description: (same as LINGST 7630). Survey of the sound patterns of English, with some comparison to other languages.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 4600 or another introductory course in linguistics or phonetics

courses.name: Syntax
courses.description: (same as LINGST 7640). Study of the properties of phrase-and sentence-level grammar, emphasizing English, with some comparison to other languages.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 4600 or another comparable linguistics course

courses.name: Field Methods in Linguistics
courses.description: (same as LINGST 7870 and ANTHRO 7870).  Provides training in the methods of constructing a detailed linguistic description and analysis of a wholly unfamiliar language, based on interviews with a native speaker.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: LINGST 1060, LINGST 7600, LINGST 7630 and LINGST 7640Corequisites: LINGST 7630 or LINGST 7640

courses.name: Special Themes in Folklore
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 7150). Intensive study in a selected area of folklore: folk narrative, folk song, myth, proverb, etc., folklore of a particular group. May be repeated for a maximum of six hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Themes in African Diaspora Folklore
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 7160 and [BL_STU 7710). Intensive study in a selected area of African Diaspora folklore: folk narrative, folk song, myth, proverb, etc., folklore and literature; or the folklore of a particular group. ENGLSH 7700 and ENGLSH 7710 may be repeated for a maximum of six hours with instructor's consent.

courses.name: Oral Tradition
courses.description: (same as CL_HUM 4770). Study of verbal art from living oral traditions (e.g., Native American and African American) and important literary works with roots in oral tradition (e.g., the Bible, the Iliad the Odyssey, and Beowulf).

courses.name: Women's Folklore and Feminist Theory
courses.description: (same as WGST 7780). Examines folklore and artistic expression of women in relation to feminist theory and in multicultural contexts. Includes verbal genres (narrative/ song) as well as material genres (quilting/arts).

courses.name: Film Theory
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 7810).   This course explore contemporary trends in film theory.  Topics may include: psychoanalysis, feminism, Marxism, cultural studies, queer theory, audience and star studies, postcolonialism, among others.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.name: Culture and Media
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 7840). Topics (e.g. Cinema and Imperialism, Indigenous Media, Ethnographic Documentary) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken for credit toward the major.

courses.name: Advanced Screenwriting: Styles
courses.description: (same as THEATR 7938; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4938, THEATR 4938).  Students develop advanced skills of screenwriting through a focus on non-realistic, non-linear dramatic writing styles in development of a full-length screenplay. Areas of study will include techniques of magic realism, symbolism, expressionism, absurdism, surrealism/dada, mythic/fantasy, musicals, political docudrama, and science fiction.

courses.name: Internship in Publishing
courses.description: Offers practical experience working with a literary or scholarly publication edited or sponsored by faculty members. Graduate students in English must take the course two semesters in order to count three hours toward the completion of their program.

courses.name: Topics in English-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Introduction to Graduate Study
courses.description: Introduces entering MA and PhD students to the profession of English and the intellectual resources needed to complete their degrees successfully.

courses.name: Professional Issues in English Studies
courses.description: Introduces advanced graduate students to issues relevant to their professional training, including entering the job market and preparing work for publication.  May be repeated for credit.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Composition
courses.description: Current and historical theories of rhetoric and composition as applied to the teaching of college composition.

courses.name: Seminar in Rhetoric and Composition
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The Institutionalization of Rhetoric, Writing Across the Curriculum) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Contemporary Critical Approaches
courses.description: A survey of contemporary professional critical methods, such as formalism, poststructuralism, feminism, Marxism, new historicism, psychoanalysis, identity studies, and cultural studies.

courses.name: Seminar in Criticism and Theory
courses.description: Principles and practices of selected critics. May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.

courses.name: History of Criticism and Theory
courses.description: A survey of the history of literary criticism and theory. While comprehensive in scope, the course might focus on specific topics in the history of criticism, such as the dialectic between rhetoric and poetics, the rise of aesthetics, or the relation of art and culture to society. Figures studied will extend from early philosophers such as Plato and Aristotle, through eighteenth-century thinkers such as Kant and Johnson, up to present theorists such as Derrida and Butler.

courses.name: Masters Thesis Research
courses.description: Leads to preparation of masters thesis. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Problems in English
courses.description: Individual work not leading to preparation of dissertation.

courses.name: Forms
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The Epic, The Epistolary Novel) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in Old English Literature
courses.description: Topics in Old English or Anglo-Saxon literature, such as Beowulf, the Exeter Book poems, or the genres of elegy, Biblical narrative, or wisdom poetry. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in Middle English Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Medieval Drama, Chaucer) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in Renaissance British Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Tudor and Stuart Drama, Shakespearean Tragedy) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in 17th-Century British Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The Metaphysical Poets, Restoration Drama) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in 18th-Century British Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The 18th-Century Novel, Historical and Biographical Prose) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in 19th-Century British Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The Later Romantics, Victorian Poetry) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in 20th-Century British Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Chief Contemporary Poets, Modernism and the Novel) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in Early American Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., Religious and Philosophical Writings, The Revolutionary Period) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in 19th Century American Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The Transcendentalists, American Realism) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Seminar in 20th-Century American Literature
courses.description: Topics (e.g., The African-American Novel, Chief Contemporary Poets) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Seminar in African Diaspora Literature
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 8400). Topic (e.g., Autobiography, Black Women Writers) announced at time of registration. May be repeated to 12 hours with departmental consent.

courses.name: Seminar in African Diaspora Theory and Literature Criticism
courses.description: (same as BL_STU 8410). Modern and contemporary African Diaspora criticism and theory including the diverse approaches to literary and cultural studies. May be repeated to 12 hours with departmental consent.

courses.name: Advanced Writing of Fiction
courses.description: Advanced fiction writing designed primarily for graduate students, with the intention of producing work of professional quality. May repeat to twelve hours with consent of instructor.

courses.name: Advanced Writing of Nonfiction Prose
courses.description: Advanced workshop in nonfiction prose primarily for graduate students intending to produce professional quality work.

courses.name: Advanced Writing of Poetry
courses.description: Advanced poetry writing designed primarily for graduate students with the intention of producing work of professional quality. May repeat to twelve hours with consent of instructor.

courses.name: Graduate Seminar in Playwriting
courses.description: (same as THEATR 8920). Seminar in theory, practice, and pedagogy of playwriting, students a mid-term in playwriting theory, a full-length play, a research paper, and a syllabus and lesson plans for an undergraduate playwriting course.

courses.name: Seminar in the English Language
courses.description: (same as LINGST 8600). Descriptive and historical studies of the English language. Topics (e.g., The Germanic Origins, Modern Syntactic Analysis) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

courses.name: Seminar in Folklore
courses.description: (same as ANTHRO 8157 and REL_ST 8700). Focus on the roots of folklore scholarship and methodology and their evolution in modern approaches to the study of oral, traditional verbal genres and their performance in natural folk groups.  May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Seminar in Oral Tradition
courses.description: Theoretical and interpretive perspectives on works of verbal art that have roots in oral tradition. Emphasis on the variety of approaches employed (performance theory oral theory, ethnopoetics, ethnography of speaking, comparative structural studies, etc.) May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.

courses.name: Doctoral Dissertation Research
courses.description: Leads to preparation of dissertation. Graded on S/U basis only.
